entry.title: Re: How can I settle a single customer in multiple custom...
entry.content:
Hi @ramuy, 

WB2R_DOC_ENTRY will be the only solution to post a Settlement document for a single customer in a multiple customer contract. 
You will have to activate the manual settlement document creation for this contract type. 

That's one of the biggest downside of using a Multiple customer contract type, it's all or nothing: create the settlement document for all relevant customer or nothing; reverse the settlement documents for all relevant customers for the same settlement date or nothing. 
This is to avoid any inconsistency for business volume selection and calculation/posting. 


Regards, 
Gauthier VICTOR

entry.title: Q3 2025 Innovations: SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Welcome to the quarterly innovation highlights for  SAP Enterprise Service Management for Q3 2025.  Here, I want to feature some key capabilities that have been released within the last three months. We invite you to register for our Q3 2025 Innovations webcast on October 14th to stay updated on further details of our latest innovations and improvements.

Please also join us at the upcoming Customer Experience Connect where we showcase how the latest AI-infused SAP CX solutions optimize operations, generate action-ready insights, and deliver delightful experiences at every step of the customer journey.

Learn more about the latest Q3  innovations across our CX portfolio here SAP CX: What‚Äôs New in Q3 2025 | SAP News Center 

.What‚Äôs New in SAP Enterprise Service Management
SAP Enterprise Management innovations streamline workflows and speed resolution in a single workspace. Tight integration with the SAP Business Suite and embedded AI deliver clearer service insights and automate manual handoffs, reducing costs and minimizing errors. Improved user experience and greater automation accelerate resolution times, lower operating expenses, and strengthen SLA adherence and customer satisfaction. Together, these advances shorten time-to-value for new services, free capacity, reduce risk, and boost organizational agility and competitive advantage. Below are the highlights:

Dispute Management with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Achieve quick time to value with AI-based data extraction from customer emails integrated with FI-AR Dispute Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This automates and streamlines dispute creation and resolution time, driving down operational costs.

Tab Grouping in Agent Desktop: Complex inquires often require several elements of contextual data that can create many open tabs. Allowing tabs to be grouped under a corresponding main session simplifies the user workspace eliminating screen clutter and boosting efficiency.

First level case categorization with Business Information Extraction: Achieve immediate operational efficiency and increased accuracy using business information extraction for first level case categorization enabling quick time to value from AI driven case categorization. Based on the Case subject and description, the LLM model classifies it under one of the matching category values from the ones configured in grouping or class.

Case Summary enhancements: Sentiment trend and sentiment graph can now be enabled in the interaction summary for additional context. Internal and/or external case notes can also be used to generate the resolution summary.

Full-screen Case Create: Service professionals can expand to full-screen from the quick create for easier visibility and convenience when creating a case.

Filter case list by custom parties: With SAP Enterprise Management spanning many use cases within an organization personalization and context is key for service professionals and managers. When providing service for various stakeholders such as a business account, employee or supplier, the case list is easily adapted for the need.

Filter emails by channel in email work center: With many email addresses maintained by customers for different stakeholders, either internal employees, suppliers, customers, etc., managers and supervisors are able to easily view the interactions coming into their teams such as  finance, sales, HR, facilities or security and compliance. This provides simplicity as well as clear visibility at supervisory levels.

 
Template visibility and restrictions: Manage email templates with ease and ensure contextual templates are available for the right departments and resources furthering governance in managing templates. 
 
Form Auto-Fill Actions: Data from backend systems (SAP & 3rd party) can easily be pulled to prepopulate form fields. This reduces time to create a request or case and removes manual entry that can be error prone.
 
 
Custom Services: Gain more flexibility and extend your capabilities without modifying the core application.  Integrate external functionality easily ensuring unified service processes and resolution from one place.

 

Additional Resources 

For more information and complete details on the most recent innovations and improvements check our What's New page on help.sap.com updated monthly.

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Sales and Service Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Re: Error Occurred during reprint processing via TCode VF...
entry.content:
Why it is happening in your case is because, in your RD00 output form, all serial numbers are being concatenated into one table row (one cell). With 433 serial numbers, the text block grows taller than the maximum allowed row height. That‚Äôs why it works up to ~381 serials (fits within 176 cm), but fails beyond that. It‚Äôs a standard Smart Forms limitation.

Some workarounds are

  • Instead of printing all serials in a single cell, design the form to loop over serial numbers and print them line by line. In Smart Forms, replace the table cell with a loop node that outputs one serial per row. This way, the form generates multiple rows, each well within the height limit.
  • If business insists on a ‚Äúblock‚Äù of serials, split them into multiple columns (e.g. 10 serials per row √ó 44 rows). This reduces row height drastically.
  • Implement logic to page‚Äëbreak after a certain number of serials (e.g. 300 per page). Remaining serials print on the next page, avoiding the 176 cm overflow.

entry.title: Re: Hide Key in SAC table using script
entry.content:
Hello,
Thank you for raising this important question about showing only the text property of a dimension in SAC tables. This behavior is common when working with live BW connections.

 

Why the Issue Occurs

When you add a dimension back to the table via scripting (addDimensionToRows), SAC resets the display setting to the default Key + Text. The setActiveDimensionProperties(..., LONG_TEXT) approach does not always override this default for BW live models.

Instead of using setActiveDimensionProperties with .LONG_TEXT, you can explicitly force the display type to Text only after adding the dimension:

dailytable.addDimensionToRows(selectedKey);

dailytable.getDimension(selectedKey).setDisplay(DisplayType.Text);

This ensures that only the description (text) of the dimension is shown, and the technical key remains hidden.

 

Comparison with Previous Script

  • Removed: var selectedKeyText = selectedKey + ".LONG_TEXT"; and the IF/ELSE with setActiveDimensionProperties.
  • Added: getDimension(selectedKey).setDisplay(DisplayType.Text); to explicitly enforce text-only display.


By applying setDisplay(DisplayType.Text), you can reliably control how dimensions are shown to end users, independent of SAC defaults. This approach keeps the table clean and user-friendly.

entry.title: Means of Transport Ranking based on Transportation Duration - SNP Planning
entry.content:
Hello All, 

We are facing an issue while performing SNP Planning. We have maintained the Transportation Lane for a SKU with enabling product specific means of transport for example as a Rail along with Transportation duration of the Means of Transport (MOT). Sometimes when the Transportation duration of Rail is more than the Transportation duration of other MOT (Example: Truck) for which Duration is less than the Rail. 

 In certain business cases for the Products in plant must be only shipped in Rail even though Transportation Duration is more because of the weight and/or other constraints than a Truck.

In above mentioned scenario when we execute SNP proposes Transportation as a Truck instead of Rail even though through Product-specific we choose is Rail.   

Maybe if someone came across similar challenges and found a workaround or any other way for SNP to respect the product specific means of transport over the Transportation duration.  

Any help regarding this matter is greatly appreciated. 

Regards, 

Venkat.

entry.title: Re: How to assign time account type for LOA leave type?
entry.content:
Dear Shaik,

I would not really recommend to assign a holiday account to a LOA, SAP says, it is not recommended (see help portal): Creating a Leave of Absence (LOA) Time Type | SAP Help Portal

As LOA will create Event Reason Entries in Job Info, it will make this very area very crowded, therefore it is better to not configure it this way. You could build something with CPI to switch the status, but please be aware, that it might affect other areas of the system.

Kind regards

Simon

entry.title: Re: ERROR AT MERGING PROJECT
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

The reason for this issue was due to an open project which has the activity "Activate Solution Capabilities" opened.

Please confirm this activity in the project before proceed with the merge in the new project created.

1989529 - Error: Check for Current Merge of Another Project During Merge of a Change Project
https://me.sap.com/notes/1989529

In case you have any further questions or issues, please reach out to me and I'll be glad to help. 

Have a great day!  

Best regards, 

Tiago 
SAP Technical Support

entry.title: A New Beginning: SAP Stammtisch Berlin on September 25th
entry.content:
Finally, it happened on September 25th: The SAP Stammtisch Berlin was back after a break of more than a year! Although we had hoped for more attendees, the small but excellent group marked an important new beginning.

The discussions were incredibly engaging and revolved around the most pressing topics in the SAP universe today. Central to our talks were the journey from the old on-premise world to the SAP Cloud and the growing use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in businesses. It became very clear how diverse the perspectives and approaches are‚Äîamong both customer decision-makers and consultants. This exchange highlighted once again how essential it is to network.

For this reason, it is certain: We will continue the Stammtisch format! We hope to attract broader interest and a larger turnout next time. We plan to make the next attempt in November 2025, likely timed with the TechEd in Berlin.

Stay tuned and join us for the next Stammtisch!

-----

Am 25.09. war es endlich so weit: Nach √ºber einem Jahr Pause fand der SAP Stammtisch Berlin wieder statt! Auch wenn wir uns √ºber mehr Teilnehmer gefreut h√§tten, markierte die kleine, aber feine Runde einen wichtigen Neuanfang.

Die Gespr√§che waren √ºberaus spannend und drehten sich um die aktuell brennendsten Themen im SAP Universum. Im Mittelpunkt standen der Weg von der alten On-Premise-Welt in die SAP Cloud und der zunehmende Einsatz von K√ºnstlicher Intelligenz (KI) in Unternehmen. Es wurde sehr deutlich, wie unterschiedlich die Perspektiven und Herangehensweisen sind ‚Äì sowohl bei Kunden-Verantwortlichen als auch bei Beratern. Dieser Austausch hat einmal mehr gezeigt, wie unerl√§sslich es ist, sich zu vernetzen.

Deshalb ist klar: Wir werden das Format des Stammtisches fortsetzen! Wir hoffen, beim n√§chsten Mal auf ein breiteres Interesse und eine gr√∂√üere Teilnahme. Den n√§chsten Anlauf nehmen wir voraussichtlich im November 2025 rund um die TechEd in Berlin.

Bleibt dran und nehmt am n√§chsten Stammtisch teil!

Vielen Dank Eric (@ezeugner) und Daniel (@danielpolzin)  f√ºr den tollen Abend und die hervorragenden Gespr√§che. Vielen Dank auch f√ºr die Bilder, Daniel@.

entry.title: SAP API MANAGEMENT - cross reference transaction in S4HANA
entry.content:
Hello Community!

As a newcomer exploring the vast SAP jungle, I‚Äôm still learning to make sense of the many data streams flowing between its different technologies.

Here‚Äôs the scenario I‚Äôm wrestling with:

  • We have API Management (API M)

  • We have SAP S/4HANA ERP

  • The two are happily talking to each other

  • First touchpoint in S/4 is the SAP Gateway

  • We can see traffic flowing in Gateway Statistics

Now, the golden question (demanding a platinum answer) is:

Does a mechanism exist to generate a unique trace identifier whenever a transaction crosses from API M into S/4?

Or phrased differently:
 Is there a way to guarantee that 1 API call in API M corresponds exactly to 1 entry in SAP Gateway Stats?

Appreciate any guidance from the seasoned explorers out there.

Best regards,
Roger, over and out

Yann
(just a regular guy looking for a short moment of enlighten)

entry.title: From Insight to Impact: Measuring Business Outcomes with Data Driven Value Management
entry.content:
In my earlier blog, published in 2022, Value Management: The Key to Successful Digital Transformation, we explored why value management forms the foundation of successful transformation programs.

Since then, SAP has significantly expanded its Business Transformation Management portfolio with solutions such as SAP Signavio, LeanIX, and WalkMe. This combined focus is helping customers look beyond technology deployments ‚Äî enabling them to improve business processes, strengthen enterprise architecture, drive solution adoption, and prepare their organizations for transformations, continuous improvement, and the emerging AI-driven future.

A key practice that has gained strong momentum is data-driven business value management ‚Äî using real process and operational data to quantify opportunities, prioritize change, and track measurable outcomes over time.

In this follow-up, we move from theory to practice ‚Äî using SAP Signavio to identify, qualify, and realize value based on real process execution data ‚Äî and building the governance model that sustains value delivery long after go-live.

Why Process Data is a Game-Changer

For years, value management relied on ROI models, benchmarks, and expert opinions. While these provided direction, they often left executives asking:

‚ÄúHow do we know this is really true for us?‚Äù

This is where process data changes everything. By leveraging execution data from your own systems, you can see exactly how your processes run, where bottlenecks exist, and what they cost ‚Äî in real time.

This shift is groundbreaking because it transforms value management from a hypothetical, static exercise into a continuous, data-driven discipline that links transformation initiatives directly to measurable business outcomes.

What Process Data Delivers

Process data ‚Äî captured through SAP Signavio Process Insights and Process Intelligence ‚Äî enables organizations to:

  • Gain full transparency ‚Äì a clear, objective view of how processes actually perform.
  • Quantify the impact ‚Äì number of cases affected, hours consumed, and cost implications.
  • Apply business context ‚Äì filter by region, product, or company code to focus on where change matters most.

Instead of ‚Äúbest-guess‚Äù benefits, you get a fact-based foundation to align business and IT on where to act first.

 

A Phased Approach to Value Realization

 Once process data is available, we follow a structured methodology to translate insights into measurable outcomes.

0. Strategic Objectives

Align with stakeholders on what success looks like ‚Äî growth, margin expansion, compliance, or efficiency ‚Äî and define value drivers that will guide prioritization.

1. Value Identification

Use Signavio to uncover inefficiencies ‚Äî blocked invoices, rework loops, excessive manual touchpoints ‚Äî and quantify their impact to create a single version of the truth.

2. Value Qualification

Collaborate with business owners to validate findings, prioritize opportunities by business impact, and develop a high-level action plan to capture value.

3. Value Monitoring

Establish the value monitoring capabilities 

  • Configuring monitoring dashboards within SAP Signavio Process Insights and Process Intelligence to track these KPIs in near real time.
  • Setting up alerts and trend analysis so that deviations from expected benefits are visible early.
  • Embedding monitoring into BAU so that value tracking becomes part of daily operational rhythm

4. Value Governance & Realization

Measure actual outcomes, verify benefits, and feed learnings into future cycles. Governance ensures accountability and turns this into a continuous loop rather than a one-off report.

Governance: The Key to Sustained Value

True value realization is not about dashboards alone ‚Äî it‚Äôs about ownership and accountability:

  • Executive Steering: Sponsors provide direction and clear roadblocks.
  • Benefit Owners: Individuals take responsibility for outcomes in their area.
  • Transparent Reporting: Progress reviews keep the organization focused on results.

Governance turns value realization into a management discipline that survives beyond project close and keeps value visible to all stakeholders.

 

Scaling Beyond Tactical Wins: Embedding Value at the Core

The journey to value realization is not just about fixing isolated problems ‚Äî it‚Äôs about making value the lens through which every initiative is planned and measured.

As shown in the graphic, organizations evolve across three dimensions:

  • Tactical: Resolve immediate pain points and stabilize operations to drive functional excellence.
  • Optimization: Move into continuous improvement and functional innovation, using process insights to elevate KPIs and operational efficiency.
  • Strategic: Orchestrate cross-functional enterprise transformation where value delivery becomes a shared, organization-wide objective.

When value is at the center, it becomes the North Star for:

  • Continuous Improvement in BAU: Incremental enhancements to keep operations efficient and compliant.
  • Functional Transformations: Major initiatives like finance transformation or supply chain modernization, measured not by go-live but by benefits delivered.
  • Enterprise-Wide Programs: Cross-functional transformations delivering outcomes like margin improvement, sustainability targets, or improved customer experience.

This ensures that every dollar invested in change is tied to measurable business outcomes, creating a culture of value-centricity where progress is continuously monitored, governed, and optimized.

 

Key Takeaways

  • Data-first approach: Process data replaces assumptions with measurable facts.
  • Governance matters: Aligns teams and ensures accountability for value delivery.
  • Continuous loop: Value identification, execution, and measurement never stop.

Call to Action

If your business cases still rely on static assumptions, it‚Äôs time to modernize. SAP Signavio can provide a fact-based baseline in days and help you build a governance-backed value framework that delivers results ‚Äî and sustains them.

entry.title: Re: How to get assignmentEndDate field to Variable Pay As...
entry.content: @swagatikapanda I had this requirement on a project where we used point in time as of 3/1 but the customer wanted to bring the salary from the last assignment of the year (so not necessarily 12/31, could be 11/1 if the person terminated on that date) into the summary level. There is a much easier solution to do this than what is documented in the blog. You simply need to bring over the salary from its varpayemphist table column into an ALCF (see number 3 of this blog) then copy its ID into a custom column you created for one of your sections (BusSection or IndSection). Once you have that in place, take the ID of the BusSection or IndSection custom column you created and paste it into a summary level custom column. Now you can also easily bring this salary of the last assignment of the year back to the Assignement level by create a new ALCF column (second one) and paste the ID of the summary level column into that ALCF column.

entry.title: System Audit Trail Reporting in SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Have you ever wondered how you can view changes made to the Approval Groups and Rules, without taking numerous screenshots or manually tracking?

In this blog, we outline the steps to view, track, and download the changes made to Approval Groups and Rules in SAP Fieldglass. Read on to find out more. You can also download this information as a one-page guide.

Prerequisites

  • The relevant Users must have access to the System Audit Trail  - this access is granted through the View System Audit Trail User Role Administrative Permission
  • Approval Groups will only appear if they exist within your workflows
  • Approval Rules appear if the existing Rule Engine company configuration is enabled and Rules have been created

How to Get Started

  1. From the Admin Menu, navigate to System Tools and select System Audit Trail
  2. Select the filter information for the data that you want to retrieve, such as User, Module, Dates, Activity
  3. Click Apply Filters
  4. Check the boxes next to the data lines that you need: This action will determine what is included in the XLSX output file
  5. Click Download Activity Data
  6. An XLSX file will be ready to download:
    • The download output will include a legend in the first row with text that states *Highlight indicates change. The rest of the header rows will include columns for System Audit Trail fields.
    • The Version column will indicate a BEFORE view of the record and the AFTER view of the record (view after Edit/Remove).
    • If an entire Approval Group or Approval Rule is removed, then the output will show all the BEFORE rows with all values highlighted. No AFTER rows will appear, as it has been removed from the database.
    • If the field isn‚Äôt applicable (no Rule/Script/Variable), a blank will appear for both BEFORE and AFTER.

Next Steps

  • Download this information as a one-page guide.
  • Visit the SAP Fieldglass Help Portal for more information about the System Audit Trail.

Unless you explicitly use the ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù filter in the pop‚Äëup, the direct search doesn‚Äôt check KNB1/LFB1 (customer/vendor company code data). That‚Äôs why you see ‚Äúextra‚Äù BPs. Either train users to use the F4 pop‚Äëup with filters or implement a custom search help / search help exit that enforces the company code restriction.

entry.title: Re: How do I apply a partial credit to an invoice? B1
entry.content: I'm a newbie, but see two solutions for that. First solution: set the same due dates for invoice and credit. Or second: while being in internal reconciliation window, the amounts next to invoice and credit are editable. Change 100$ into 10$ next to invoice. Now both invoice and credit can be reconciled into zero. You should be left with 90$ to pay.

entry.title: SAP B1 IR/GR 8% threshold, invoice/credit posting
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I need your advice on how to correctly post two documents‚Äîan invoice and a credit memo‚Äîwhen the 8% tolerance limit is active. As you know, this setting prevents invoice posting if the difference between the goods receipt (GR) and the invoice receipt (IR) exceeds 8%.

Here is the scenario:

  • A purchase order (PO) was created for ‚Ç¨800.

  • A GR was posted for ‚Ç¨800.

  • The supplier mistakenly issued an invoice for ‚Ç¨2,400, and later issued a credit memo for ‚Ç¨1,600 to correct the error.

When attempting to post the ‚Ç¨2,400 invoice, SAP throws an error due to the IR exceeding the GR by more than 8%.

My question:
Is the only way to proceed as follows?

  1. Cancel the original GR.

  2. Adjust the PO amount from ‚Ç¨800 to ‚Ç¨2,400.

  3. Re-post the GR for ‚Ç¨2,400.

  4. Post the ‚Ç¨2,400 invoice.

  5. Finally, post the ‚Ç¨1,600 credit memo.

Is there a better or more efficient approach to handle this situation within SAP?

Thanks in advance for your help!

Best regards,

Tom

entry.title: Re: Send reminders to Onboardees to complete pending tasks
entry.content: If you would like to trigger reminders until the task is completed, please set the following conditions: "Number of reminders to be sent" = 0. You can also change the "Frequency of reminders in days" to 1, this will ensure daily emails are sent until the task is completed. "Frequency of reminders in days" controls the time span between reminders sent before due date.

entry.title: Delivery error- wrong recipient address
entry.content:
Hello Expert team,

We are configuring the Purchase Order Entry app in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, to enable automatic email delivery of purchase order reports to our suppliers. The supplier‚Äôs email address is maintained via their contact person‚Äôs record.

However, when a contact person leaves the organization and their email remains in our records, any attempt to send reports to that address will not generate an obvious error. The system continues to show the purchase order status as ‚ÄúSent‚Äù and the Monitor Email Transmissions app reflects the status as ‚Äúsucceeded.‚Äù This means we don‚Äôt receive a Non-Delivery Receipt or alert if an email address is no longer valid.

What options or best practices are available to proactively detect and manage cases where outbound purchase order emails do not actually reach the intended recipient, especially if the contact information is outdated?

Thank you for your feedback.

Best

Jack

entry.title: New Critical Content Now Live in the SAP Support Portal: Empowering You with Faster, Smarter Support
entry.content:
We‚Äôre excited to introduce Critical Content, now available in the Support by Product Pages in the SAP Support Portal, bringing you faster access to the most essential resources for your product.

What Is Critical Content?

Critical Content includes expert-recommended articles and solutions that address the most severe issues‚Äîthose that could lead to major business disruptions if not addressed in time. These resources are now surfaced directly on your product‚Äôs support page, making it easier than ever to stay informed and take action.

You may already be familiar with Hot Content, which highlights major issues that could impact a large number of customers and typically result in support requests if no guidance is provided. Trending Content shows you what other customers are viewing most today. These are the most-accessed solutions across the platform‚Äîreal-time insights into what‚Äôs relevant and helpful right now.

Critical Content, on the other hand, focuses on high-impact issues specific to your product‚Äîthose that could cause serious business consequences if overlooked. It‚Äôs about proactive support, helping you resolve problems before they escalate.

Here it is a screen shot of a product page on the SAP Support Portal showing one Critical KBA as example:

See Also:

Expanding Proactive Solutions: Critical Content now Live in SAP for Me

Unlocking Proactive Solutions: Preventative Content now Live in SAP for Me

entry.title: Optimizing SAP Analytics Cloud ‚Äì Best Practices and Performance
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) offers powerful capabilities for planning, analytics, and business intelligence‚Äîall in one unified platform. But to truly unlock its potential, it's essential to follow best practices that ensure optimal performance, scalability, and maintainability. In this blog, we‚Äôll explore some of the insights and recommendations across four key pillars of SAC:

  • Analytics & Planning Modeling: Structuring your models for flexibility, performance, and future growth.
  • Calculations: Designing efficient formulas and leveraging SAC‚Äôs calculation engine wisely.
  • Data Actions: Automating planning workflows with precision and minimal overhead.
  • Story Building: Crafting intuitive, responsive, and insightful dashboards that drive decision-making.

Performance Considerations

Performance in SAC isn‚Äôt a post-implementation concern‚Äîit must be a core priority from the very beginning of your project. Striking the right balance between rich functionality and responsive performance is essential. While functional requirements drive business value, they must be matched by a system that performs reliably and efficiently. Performance optimization touches every layer of your SAC solution: from backend data architecture and model design to story layout, user concurrency, and even device and network configurations.

Model Design

  • Model Scope: Clearly define the model‚Äôs scope, type (planning or analytics), required metrics, and data granularity based on business objectives. This clarity prevents over engineering and ensures alignment with user needs.
  • Reusability: Build modular models that can be reused across multiple stories and planning scenarios. Reusability reduces duplication, simplifies maintenance, and accelerates development cycles.
  • Lean Model Structure: Key performance drivers include the number of measures, dimensions, hierarchies, and members per dimension. Reducing unnecessary dimensions and avoiding overly complex hierarchies directly improves query performance and system responsiveness. Focus on dimensions that are essential for data collection. Attributes such as geographic area or gender can often be derived rather than modeled as standalone dimensions. Evaluate whether static dimensions can be converted into attributes, and consider splitting large models into smaller, purpose-driven ones. Simpler models are easier to maintain, faster to calculate, and more memory efficient. Avoid adding dimensions or calculations unless they deliver clear business value.
  • Understanding Model Types: From a performance perspective, Analytic Models connected to live data sources place minimal demand on SAC infrastructure, as most of the processing load is handled by the source system itself. In contrast, Analytic Models using acquired data rely on the embedded HANA database, primarily for read operations. While this does introduce some system load, it tends to be moderate and more CPU-intensive than memory-intensive. Planning Models with acquired data, however, offer richer functionality but come with higher resource requirements‚Äîimpacting both CPU and memory. Their performance is heavily influenced by model design factors such as the number of exception aggregations, the complexity and volume of dimensions, and the breadth of the user‚Äôs security context during data entry operations.
  • Additional performance-critical factors include the number of concurrent users, the volume and structure of the data, and the frequency and complexity of scheduled jobs or data actions also play a significant role in determining system responsiveness and scalability.
  • Use Measure Based Model: When designing models in SAC, opting for a Measure-Based Model is highly recommended due to its significant advantages in performance, calculation flexibility, and overall modeling efficiency.
    • Enhanced Performance & Scalability: Measure-based models are optimized for faster processing and reduced complexity, especially in large-scale planning scenarios.
    • Flexible Structure: These models support both accounts and measures, with the account dimension now optional giving you greater design freedom.
    • Reusable Calculations: You can define base measure calculations that simplify logic reuse across stories and planning workflows.
    • Advanced Aggregation: Measures can be aggregated more efficiently, improving responsiveness and reducing load times.
    • Expanded Data Type Support: Measure-based models accommodate a wider range of data types, enhancing versatility.
    • Multi-Currency Planning: With base currency measures, currency conversion becomes seamless, enabling planning across multiple currencies with ease.

Dimension Design

  • Leverage Public Dimensions: Use the Public Dimension feature to manage master data independently, allowing for centralized updates and reuse across models. Avoid importing all source system tables‚Äîfocus only on dimensions relevant to data entry and planning.
  • Dimension hierarchies and members: Deep hierarchies can be resource intensive. Limit the number of levels to reduce complexity and improve query performance. Keep the number of members in each dimension‚Äîincluding the Account dimension‚Äîlean. Import only valid members and apply filters to exclude irrelevant data.
  • Date Dimension: Use SAC‚Äôs standard date dimension with SAP-managed hierarchies (Year‚ÄìQuarter‚ÄìMonth‚ÄìDay) to minimize performance impact.

Planning Area

  • The planning area defines the specific slice of data within a model that end users can interact with‚Äîwhether through stories or data actions. When users plan on a public version in a story, SAC automatically creates an implicit private version behind the scenes. This version isn‚Äôt visible to the user but introduces system overhead, especially in models with large datasets or when multiple users are editing simultaneously. To mitigate this, it‚Äôs crucial to explicitly define the planning area in the model settings and enable it within the story. Doing so significantly reduces resource consumption during public version edits. Key recommendations include:
  • Configure a Targeted Planning Area: Set a focused scope based on business needs, using data access control, data locking, or both to restrict editable data.
  • Avoid Full Dataset Scope: Limiting the planning area prevents unnecessary data loading and improves performance.
  • Use Data Access Control(DAC): Define which users can write to specific dimensions‚Äîsuch as company codes or profit centers‚Äîto ensure secure and relevant access.
  • Apply Data Locking: Protect actuals from being overwritten by locking them from edits.
  • Enable Dynamic Planning Area: Set ‚ÄúAuto-generate based on table context‚Äù as the default. This allows the planning area to adjust automatically based on filters, story context, or table layout‚Äîensuring users only load what they need.

SAC Planning Best Practices

  • Use Unbooked Data selectively: Enable unbooked data only when necessary‚Äîtypically for planning use cases. Since it triggers resource-intensive backend queries, it's best disabled for reporting scenarios to preserve performance.
  • Implement DAC: Always activate DAC on relevant dimensions to enforce row-level security. This ensures users only see and interact with data within their authorized scope, reducing system load during public version edits. DAC should be configured during the model design phase. DAC can be turned ON in the Model Dimension through the Read/Write Property or the Data Access Filter in Role by turning the Model Data Privacy ON so DAC can be combined with role-based restrictions. Use DAC primarily on planning-relevant dimensions (E.g. Cost Center, Profit Center, Region), not on all dimensions.
  • Complement with Data Locks :  While DAC governs who can read/write data, Data Locks control when data can be modified (e.g., freezing approved budgets). This combination enhances performance, especially in multi-user environments. Minimize driving dimensions when using data locking to reduce overhead.
  • Define Validation Rules: Ensure users can only edit valid combinations of dimension members. This is particularly important for models with large dimension tables and helps maintain data integrity while improving performance.
  • Limit Private versions: Excessive private versions‚Äîespecially when multiple users are editing simultaneously‚Äîcan strain system resources. Regularly clean up unused private versions to maintain system efficiency.
  • Manage Date Granularity: For models with day-level granularity, consider isolating them into separate models. Use cross-model copy data actions to transfer aggregated data, reducing complexity and improving performance.
  • Use Modeler option ‚ÄòOptimize Story Building Performance‚Äô : This prevents the automatic refresh of data during story design. When importing or writing back datasets, use filters or pre-aggregation to reduce data volume

Calculations/Data Actions

  • Prioritize Model-Level Formulas: Define calculations within the modeler rather than at the story level to reduce query load and improve responsiveness.
  • Offload Complex: Logic to Data Actions Use data actions for advanced formulas and heavy computations instead of embedding them directly in stories.
  • Restrict Execution Scope: Use the MEMBERSET statement to narrow the scope of data actions. A tightly defined scope minimizes processing time and resource usage.
  • Limit Iteration Range: Keep calculation loops (IF, FOREACH) as focused as possible. Broad iteration across dimensions can degrade performance.
  • Aggregate at the Highest Logical Level: Design calculations to occur at the most aggregated node feasible to reduce data volume and complexity.
  • Avoid Copying Calculated Accounts: Copying calculated accounts or non-standard aggregations is resource intensive. Prefer copying raw fact data when possible.
  • Configure Advanced Formulas Thoughtfully: All steps in advanced formulas execute sequentially and materialize in the model. Use variable members to streamline logic and avoid unnecessary commits.
  • Minimize Query Calls: Reduce the number of DATA() and RESULTLOOKUP() statements‚Äîeach call triggers a backend query.
  • Restricted Measures Over Exception Aggregations: Exception aggregations (e.g., MIN, MAX, AVERAGE across hierarchies) are computationally expensive. Use restricted measures and advanced formulas when possible.
  • Simplify Formula Structures: Avoid breaking formulas into too many sub-steps, which increases processing overhead.
  • Recompile After Model Changes:  If performance drops after model updates, re-save the advanced formula or data action to trigger recompilation and optimization.
  • Centralize Execution for Large Volumes:  Run data actions centrally via an admin user when handling large datasets. For decentralized execution, ensure scope is tightly defined.
  • Trigger Actions Judiciously:  Avoid frequent or unnecessary data action runs. Execute only when required to conserve resources.
  • Monitor Execution Time:  Use the Data Action Monitor to track duration and identify slow-running actions.
  • Use Job Monitor for Diagnostics: Regularly review run history and step-level details to pinpoint bottlenecks and optimize performance.
  • Simplify IF Statements: Reduce reliance on IF statements by using logical operators like AND or applying filters. Each IF creates a subquery, so use sparingly.
  • Leverage Predictive Planning: Use predictive features to generate accurate forecasts based on historical data, accelerating planning cycles and improving decision-making.

Backend HANA/BW considerations

HANA modelling

  • Optimize HANA Views by following guidelines for modelling and performance tuning.
  • Perform Calculations Post-Aggregation: Whenever possible, structure views to calculate after aggregation to reduce data volume and improve speed.
  • Join on Indexed Columns: Use keys or indexed columns for joins instead of calculated fields to enhance query performance.
  • Push Logic to HANA: Keep calculations and logic within HANA to leverage pushdown capabilities and minimize SAC-side processing.
  • Blend in HANA, Not SAC: Perform data linking and blending operations in HANA to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Apply Filters Early: Early filtering reduces data load and improves query execution time.
  • Hide Unused Dimensions in SAC: Remove unnecessary metadata from SAC models to streamline performance and reduce clutter.

BW modelling

  • Design Efficient Queries: Limit the number of dimensions and hide unnecessary key figures to reduce query payload and improve responsiveness.
  • Use BW Variables Over SAC Filters: BW variables are processed server-side and offer better performance than applying filters within SAC stories.
  • Define Restricted Key Figures: in BW Avoid creating restricted key figures in SAC remote models. Instead, configure them directly in BW for optimized execution.
  • Minimize Cascading Page Filters: Page-level filters that trigger cascading effects across widgets can slow down performance. Use them sparingly and strategically.
  • Enable Query Merge: Activate query merge to consolidate backend calls, reducing latency and improving load times.
  • Enable HTTP/2 Protocol: Improves data transfer efficiency between SAC and BW, especially for large datasets.
  • Increase Parallel Sessions: Configure BW data sources to support more parallel sessions, enhancing concurrency and user experience.
  • Apply BI Authorizations for Data Security: Use BW‚Äôs built-in data-level security to control access and ensure users only retrieve data relevant to their roles.

Story Building Recommendations

Story Structure & Layout

  • Use Optimized or Unified Story Experience: Adopt the latest story building interface for enhanced performance, flexibility, and design capabilities.
  • Leverage Composites as Reusable Widgets: Composites are stored as SAC artifacts and can be reused across stories. They support both canvas and responsive layouts and allow story-level features like filters and bookmarks to apply seamlessly. Benefits include faster story creation, reduced maintenance, standardized design, and support for parallel development.
  • Use Responsive Layouts: Responsive pages automatically adjust to screen size and load faster. Unified stories offer advanced responsive rule configurations for precise control.

Content Design & Performance Optimization

  • Request Only What‚Äôs Needed: Break down information into manageable layers. Use summary or landing pages with hyperlinks to detailed views.
  • Minimize Page Count and Widget Load: Reduce the number of pages and limit data-heavy widgets per page to improve load times and user experience.
  • Optimize Charts and Tables:
    • Avoid charts with more than 500 data points.
    • Limit the number of charts per page to reduce backend requests.
    • Split large tables into smaller ones with fewer KPIs or measures.
    • Limit the number of cells and descriptive columns for readability.
    • Avoid excessive formatting rules and in-cell charts/calculations.
  • Use Lightweight Visuals:  Replace large image files with lightweight SVGs to reduce rendering time.

Filtering & Data Handling:

  • Implement Filters Strategically: Apply filters at the document level rather than creating generic views. Use page filters instead of individual chart filters. Avoid loading all data and filtering afterward.
  • Limit Hierarchy Depth: in Filters Deep hierarchies can slow down performance‚Äîuse only necessary levels.
  • Minimize Data Blending: Sources Keep the number of blended data sources low to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Pause Data Refresh During Design: Use the ‚ÄúPause Data Refresh‚Äù option to optimize story loading while building.

Security & Access Control

  • Test With User Roles: Validate story performance using roles with end user authorizations‚Äînot just the admin role‚Äîto simulate real-world usage.
  • Apply Data Access Control (DAC): Ensure users only see data relevant to their role. For example, use filters for company code and profit center rather than displaying all dimensions.

Planning-Specific Tips

  • Use Fluid Data Entry Mode: This default mode offers better performance and interactivity. Avoid Single Data Entry mode, which is slower.
  • Enable Planning Only Where Needed: Activate planning features on tables only when required. Disable planning in the builder panel if not used.

Latest Performance Improvements

  • New Table Build Experience:  Optimized Stories ‚Äì Edit Mode Enhancements.
    • Blended Tables: Initial page loading is faster.
    • Calculations: Automatically retained when tables are copied.
    • Improved Filtering & Sorting: More efficient workflows and reduced query errors.
    • Ghost Table: Instant layout preview before data loads
  • Story Design Optimization:
    • Performance recommendations in Edit Mode available for story designers in the optimized story experience.
    • Available for widget, page, and stories levels.
  • Preload pages
    • It can be enabled in edit mode under Data Refresh->Loading Optimization Settings-> Preload Pages.
    • Preloading will initialize parts of the next and previous page, so switching to these pages will now be faster.

If performance issues persist despite optimization efforts, SAC offers a suite of diagnostic tools to help pinpoint the root cause. These tools provide visibility into query execution, data action performance, and story load behavior. For detailed guidance on using these diagnostics, refer to the official SAP Help documentation or reach out to SAP Support for expert help.

entry.title: Display of Opening Movement from balance carryforward in DRC AR_JOURNAL_LEDGER
entry.content:
Hello SAP Support,

We are implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, and have encountered the following situation:

The balance carryforward does not generate an FI document; instead, it posts the opening balances in Period 0 (ACDOCA). From an accounting perspective this is acceptable, but the customer requires that the legal Journal of Argentine (Libro Diario) reflects the ‚Äúopening / balance reclassification‚Äù movement resulting from the carryforward.

Question:
Is there a standard way for DRC object AR_JOURNAL_LEDGER to display this opening movement?

If this is not supported, what best practice or recommended alternative would you suggest to meet the legal Journal requirement? The key issue is that, since the carryforward in Public Edition does not create an FI document, AR_JOURNAL_LEDGER‚Äîbeing document-based‚Äîdoes not show the opening movement.

We would greatly appreciate your guidance on whether this requirement can be met with standard content, or alternatively the recommended approach to ensure compliance.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,

entry.title: Archive SAC Change Docs into Datasphere
entry.content:
Using SAC data change documents, you can track (audit) the data changes made to any planning model. SAP Analytics Cloud logs all changes to the transaction data of that model when users publish data from private versions to public versions.

Note that a data change log has up to 2^31 (i.e., 2,147,384,648, or ~2 billion) records. When the data change log reaches its size limit, publishing data will fail, and you will see the following message:

Publish cannot be performed because the data audit table has reached the maximum number of rows.

To avoid this issue, consider periodically downloading log entries as a backup before deleting them.

 

This document shows a design to back up SAC audit logs into Datasphere. Using Datasphere dataflow to backup change documents from the SAC Data Export Service via Cloud Data Integration adapter-based connection, it can backup and preserve the SAC audit logs history concerning the regular housekeeping needed in SAC due to the storage capacity limit.

 

DES: data export service

CDI: cloud data integration

 

Note: In SAC seamless planning or in BDC, the SAC model definition and calculation logic remain within SAC, while the persistence for planning data and change documents are stored in SAP Datasphere, so that both systems are closely linked - without the effort of manual data transfers. Therefore, the solution might not be necessary if the SAC change documents are already stored in Datasphere.



 

The following are the steps to implement the solution.

In SAC, System ‚Äì Administration ‚Äì App Integration, create an OAuth client with Access to the Data Export Service.

 

 

In SAC, keep the OAuth Client URLs for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

 

In SAC, copy the OAuth Client ID and Client Secret for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

 

In Datasphere, in a space, create a Cloud Data Integration connection pointing to the SAC Data Export Service. The URL is in the format of

https://<your domain>/api/v1/dataexport/administration

 

 

In the connections management screen, validate the connection, and make sure the Data Flows feature is now enabled. It shall give the following message after validation on the connection.

Connection ‚ÄúSAC DES Change Docs‚Äù is valid. ‚Äì Data flows are enabled. ‚Äì Replication flows are not supported. ‚Äì Remote tables are enabled.

 

In SAC, open the model with the Audit Data flag switched on, and note down the model ID in the rear part of the URL. For instance:

https://<your domain name>/sap/fpa/ui/app.html?sap-ui-theme=sap_belize#/modeler&/m/model/C4003n1icbi0loo9lvgv7t4pu41

 

In Datasphere, Data Builder- Create a Data Flow to load SAC audit logs into a target table.

  1. Use the model id to find the SAC source in the connection for the source node in the data flow.
  2. To make the daily backup more efficient, an exemplary expression implemented in the projection node can be: "Audit_Time" >= ADD_DAYS(NOW(), -1).
  3. To preserve the audit logs history that might be regularly cleaned in SAC, use Append mode on the target table for UPSERT.

 

 

 

 

In Datasphere, execute the data flow to load SAC audit logs and verify that the data is now present in Datasphere. Then, delete the audit logs in SAC, execute the data flow again to check that the audit logs history has been preserved after cleansing audit logs in SAC.

 

 

Last but not least, you may also develop an analytic model on top of the audit logs history table in Datasphere for analytics and build a report or visualization in SAC.

Note:

CDI connection type also supports the remote table as well as the data flow feature.

Remote table can use the following replication types, but none of those replications can well preserve the change document history.

  • Replication (snapshot)
  • Replication (real-time)
